Award.AwardTitle: Acquisition of a gas source mass spectrometer for high precision - high sensitivity (delta)17O and (delta)18O analyses of silicates
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will provide funds for the acquisition of a high sensitivity/high precision gas source mass spectrometer as a foundation for our new research program involving high-spatial resolution and ultra-high precision triple oxygen isotope geochemistry. This exciting technique of measuring small variations in 17O values of geological materials is in its infancy, with many potential applications across a broad spectrum within Earth Sciences. The application of ultra-high resolution 17O measurements will be an integral part of the thesis work for three incoming graduate students (one woman) and will ultimately serve to demonstrate to the broader geological community the potential for this new technology. The facility will be available to outside users with relevant research projects. It will serve as a platform for future NSF proposals involving student research.

The high precision mass spectrometer is the basic platform for a number of research themes,including constraining paleoclimate variations, understanding Deep-Time climate, tracking near-surface signatures in shallow crustal and mantle rocks, measuring individual zircons extracted from lunar and Archean terrestrial rocks, meteoritic studies, and other evolving projects. This equipment will be the primary research tool of the two PIs and will compliment other advances being instituted in the newly formed University-wide Center for Stable Isotopes (CSI).

POR.DRECONTENT:
This proposal funded a new state-of-the-art mass spectrometer especially configured for the triple isotope analysis of oxygen.  It is now clear that there are subtle fractionations in the three isotope system 16O-17O-18O that are directly related to temperature. Whereas the 18O/16O ratio has been used for 50 years to estimate the temperature of formation of authigenic minerals, it is only recently realized that adding the 17O/16O ratio provides additional information. In order for this geochemical technique to be useful, it is necessary to measure the abundance of the three isotopes to the highest precision possible. Our existing mass spectrometer did not have the necessary precision, hence the impetus for this request. 

 The mass spectrometer has been installed and is meeting all expectations. We have analyzed quartz and silica precipitated at low (and known) temperatures in order to calibrate the relationship between 18O/16O and 17O/16O. The temperature dependent equation that we developed is given by lnα17O/16O = Θ lnα18O/16O, where Θ = (1.85±0.04)/T + 0.5305 (T in Kelvin). This work has just been published (Sharp, Z.D. et al., A calibration of the triple oxygen isotope fractionation in the SiO2-H2O system and application to natural samples, Geochim. Cosmochim. Acta  doi:10.1016/j.gca.2016.04.047). The calibration curve is shown in Fig. 1. With the robust Θ-T relationship, we are able to apply this new method to unknown samples. Figure 2 gives an illustration of the power of this new method. A quartz 'geode' from Morocco was analyzed for the triple oxygen isotope composition of the quartz crystals lining the geode. The measured data are shown as the green spot in Fig. 2. The black curved line is the combined Δ'17O and δ'18O values of water in equilibrium with this sample (Δ'17O = δ'17O - 0.528 δ'18O) as a function of temperature. The 'tick marks' on the curve represent equilibrium temperatures. By assuming only that the sample was in equilibrium with meteoric water (shown by the blue band for the global triple isotope meteoric water line), it is possible to infer that the temperature of formation was ~50ºC with a meteoric water that had a δ'18O value of ~ -6‰. The modern meteoric water in Morocco is shown as the vertical grey band, suggesting that our analysis accurately provided an estimate of both temperature and δ'18O value of the meteoric water.

We have expanded this work. As part of her Master's thesis, Jordan Gibbons has analyzed silica precipitated from a geothermal plant in Iceland. These samples are an ideal natural laboratory to refine our calibration over a temperature range of 60 to 118ºC. Jordan has the silica, the water and the temperature of formation. When her data are plotted on a graph of the form of Fig. 2, her temperature estimates from the measured quartz and water give results that are within 1ºC of the measured temperature. Clearly the system is working very well. She has also visited Chile to collect silica from sinters that are presently being deposited. Unlike the geothermal samples, the Chilean samples appear to be far out of equilibrium. This work will constitute her Master's thesis.

Unlike the geothermal samples, the Chilean samples appear to be far out of equilibrium. This work will constitute her Master's thesis. Our continued work will be centered on calcite in place of quartz. Calcite is far more difficult to measure for the triple oxygen isotope ratios, but we believe that we have developed a method that will allow for accurate measurements. This work, to be started in the summer of 2016, is the Ph.D. of Jordan Gibbons. Additional work planned for the future includes looking at manganese nodules, which have prior evidence of atmospheric water incorporated into the samples. We have presented this work at AGU in 2015 and Jordan will present her work at the Goldschmidt Conference in Yokahama Japan in summer of 2016. Last Modified: 05/08/2016 Submitted by: Zachary D Sharp
